metadata.dsm5_code: 296.xx (specify current or most recent episode and features)

content.description: Bipolar I Disorder is characterized by at least one lifetime manic episode, often with recurrent depressive and hypomanic episodes. Mania involves a distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and increased energy/activity, causing marked impairment, need for hospitalization, or psychosis.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. ≥1 manic episode (≥1 week or any duration if hospitalization required) with abnormally elevated/expansive/irritable mood and increased energy plus ≥3 (≥4 if mood only irritable) of: inflated self-esteem/grandiosity; decreased need for sleep; pressured speech; flight of ideas; distractibility; increased goal-directed activity/psychomotor agitation; risky activities. B. Episode causes marked impairment or requires hospitalization or includes psychotic features. C. Not attributable to a substance/medical condition. Major depressive episodes are common but not required for diagnosis.
content.prevalence: Lifetime ~1%; similar across sexes. High rates of underdiagnosis/misdiagnosis early in course.
content.age_of_onset: Late adolescence to early adulthood; can occur across lifespan.
content.prognosis: Recurrent, episodic course with variable inter-episode recovery. Early recognition, maintenance mood stabilization, psychotherapy, and substance-use management improve functional outcomes and reduce relapse/suicide risk.

circuitry: Dysregulation in fronto-limbic networks (ventromedial/dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, amygdala, anterior cingulate) affecting emotion regulation and impulse control.
Abnormal reward and salience processing in striatum and insula; altered thalamo-cortical synchronization.
neurochemistry: Perturbations in monoamines (dopamine, serotonin, norepinephrine) and glutamate/GABA balance.
Neuroendocrine and inflammatory signaling differences (HPA axis, cytokines) associated with mood state changes.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: High heritability (polygenic). Sleep/circadian disruption, substance use, and psychosocial stress act as triggers in vulnerable individuals.

history_psychosocial: Longitudinal timeline of mood episodes, sleep/circadian patterns, psychosis, hospitalizations, suicidality, and functional impairment.
Family psychiatric history; trauma and psychosocial stressors; substance use (alcohol, cannabis, stimulants).
medical_assessment: Rule out secondary causes and substances: medication review (steroids, stimulants), urine toxicology as indicated.
Screen labs: CBC, CMP, TSH, pregnancy test when relevant; consider B12, folate; ECG if cardiac risk/antipsychotic use.
standardized_measures: Young Mania Rating Scale (YMRS) for mania; Montgomery–Åsberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS) or PHQ-9 for depression.
Mood Disorder Questionnaire (MDQ) for lifetime bipolar features; Columbia-Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS) for suicide risk.
risk_stratification: Hospitalize for severe mania, psychosis, suicidal/homicidal risk, severe agitation, or marked impairment/refusal of care.
differential_diagnosis: Substance/medication-induced mood disorder; ADHD; Borderline Personality Disorder; Schizoaffective Disorder; Bipolar II; Cyclothymic Disorder; medical causes (hyperthyroidism, Cushing’s, neurologic disease).
evaluation.team_and_process: Shared management among psychiatry, primary care, and (when relevant) OB-GYN/neurology; include family/partners for collateral and relapse planning.

mania_hypomania: Decreased need for sleep with high energy
Pressured speech and flight of ideas
psychosis_possible: Mood-congruent or incongruent delusions/hallucinations during manic or depressive episodes

severity_levels.mild: Symptoms noticeable but manageable; limited functional impact; outpatient care.
severity_levels.moderate: Clear functional impairment in work/school/relationships; may require intensive outpatient or partial hospital.
severity_levels.severe: Marked impairment, psychosis, or dangerousness; often requires inpatient stabilization.

environmental: Sleep deprivation, shift work, jet lag

impact_on_life.school_work: Absenteeism, erratic performance, financial/legal problems from risky behavior.
impact_on_life.social: Relationship conflict, stigma, impulsive decisions with lasting consequences.
impact_on_life.medical: Metabolic/cardiovascular risk from medications and lifestyle; injuries during mania.

acute_mania: First-line mood stabilizer or atypical antipsychotic; combination therapy for severe or psychotic mania.
Examples: lithium; valproate; antipsychotics such as haloperidol, risperidone, olanzapine, quetiapine, aripiprazole, ziprasidone, cariprazine, asenapine.
bipolar_depression: Quetiapine; lurasidone (often with mood stabilizer); cariprazine; lamotrigine (more for prevention, modest acute effect).
Avoid antidepressant monotherapy; if used, combine with a mood stabilizer and monitor closely for switch.
maintenance_relapse_prevention: Lithium (suicide risk reduction); valproate; lamotrigine; quetiapine; aripiprazole and other SGAs as indicated.
Psychoeducation, relapse-signature monitoring, and adherence support.
psychotherapy: CBT tailored for bipolar depression and adherence.
Interpersonal and Social Rhythm Therapy (IPSRT) for circadian stabilization.
Family-Focused Therapy (FFT) to reduce expressed emotion and improve communication.
Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) skills for emotion regulation and impulsivity.
neuromodulation: Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT) for severe, psychotic, or treatment-resistant mania or depression, or when rapid response is needed.
Repetitive TMS as adjunct for bipolar depression (specialist-guided; evidence evolving).
lifestyle_interventions: Strict sleep–wake routines; light hygiene; limit substances and caffeine.
Regular aerobic activity; nutrition; weight/metabolic monitoring.
Structured daily routines; stress management; digital relapse tracking.
medications: Mood stabilizers: lithium, valproate/divalproex, lamotrigine, carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine (selected cases).
Atypical antipsychotics: quetiapine, lurasidone, olanzapine, risperidone, paliperidone, aripiprazole, ziprasidone, asenapine, cariprazine; clozapine for refractory cases with careful monitoring.
Monitoring: lithium levels/renal/thyroid; valproate levels/LFTs/platelets; carbamazepine CBC/LFTs/sodium; SGA metabolic labs (weight, lipids, glucose).
Reproductive considerations: avoid valproate in pregnancy when possible; discuss contraception/teratogenic risks; coordinate perinatal plans.
care_coordination: Safety planning and suicide risk management.
Shared decision-making; advance directives for relapse plans.
Communication with family/supports (with consent) and employers/schools for accommodations as needed.

treatment_goals: Rapidly stabilize acute mania or bipolar depression.
Prevent relapse and reduce episode frequency/severity.
Minimize adverse effects and medical comorbidity.
Restore role functioning and quality of life; reduce suicide risk.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Presenting only with depression; hypomanic/manic history not elicited.
Attributing decreased sleep and energy to work stress or ADHD without assessing euphoria/irritability and impairment.
Substance use obscuring manic symptoms; episodes mistaken for personality or situational crises.
Cultural norms of high energy/expressiveness masking pathologic elevation.
overdiagnosis_factors: Diagnosing based on brief irritability or stimulant intoxication without sustained manic syndrome.
Labeling ADHD, Borderline Personality Disorder, or cyclothymia as Bipolar I without clear manic episodes.
Using screening tools (e.g., MDQ) as sole basis without clinical interview.
Misattributing antidepressant side effects or sleep loss to mania without full criteria.

episode_specifiers: With mood-congruent or mood-incongruent psychotic features

warning_signs: Reduced need for sleep without fatigue; escalating goal-directed activity.
Increased spending, risky sex, or impulsive decisions.
Emerging psychotic features or agitation; suicidal ideation in depression or mixed states.
self_help_strategies: Consistent sleep–wake times and daily routines; avoid night shifts.
Track early warning signs (sleep change, irritability, spending); share plan with supports.
Limit alcohol/cannabis/stimulants; build a crisis plan and support network.

adolescence: Often first manic episode; higher risk of substance use and school disruption; strong family involvement and school accommodations help.
young_adulthood: Role transitions (college/work/relationships); adherence and sleep regularity are central to relapse prevention.
midlife_older_adults: Medical comorbidity/polypharmacy considerations; monitor cognition, renal/thyroid (lithium), metabolic risk with SGAs.

real_life_examples: A 20-year-old stops sleeping for 3 nights, feels invincible, spends large sums online, and argues with roommates; hospitalized and stabilized with lithium plus an antipsychotic; IPSRT prevents future relapses.

A 34-year-old with recurrent depression reveals a prior week-long period of euphoria, decreased sleep, and risky driving after a promotion; switched from SSRI alone to quetiapine plus lamotrigine, with CBT and family-focused therapy.
content.when_to_seek_help: Urgent evaluation for mania with unsafe behavior, psychosis, or suicidal/homicidal risk. Prompt care for new-onset severe insomnia, escalating spending/risk-taking, or depressive episodes with suicidality.

positive_factors: Early sustained mood stabilization (e.g., lithium) and psychotherapy
Supportive family/low expressed emotion; regular routines
challenging_factors: Comorbid substance use, mixed features, rapid cycling
High psychosocial stress or hostile/critical family climate
